physDesc.p: The letter consists of two sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of each. At the bottom of the first page there is some handwriting, intended to be inserted into the letter. On the top of the second page in the left corner is “R.A.–2” to mark the page number, and in the right corner is the date. There are a few places where words are scratched out and exchanged with written words in pencil.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: This is the Preface. I believe Fletcher has written to you about it already. It consists of the very best that Fletcher and I can do. It has been written, and written, and rewritten, and we have thought it out very carefully and verified all our illustrations. I think that it explains our position a little better than anything we have had so far, for the great difficulty now, I think, is misunderstanding. People are beginning to accept us, but they are still a little bit at sea as to what it all means, and I think the best thing we can do now is to explain ourselves, our position, and the rules by which we do our work. We have tried to make this as clear as possible. I took it in and read it to Ferris Greenslet the other day, and he thinks it the best thing that has been written on the subject. He was so much taken with it that he wants to issue it as a separate circular, as he thinks it will do everything to help the sale of the book.

Of course, you are at liberty to change it if you see fit, but I rather hope you won’t change it, as I think a thing gone over too many times loses its unity, and I am sure there is nothing here that we cannot all subscribe to, and as you people did not offer a preface this year, we thought we had better offer you one. I would suggest that, if you can, you leave it exactly as it is, and then you on your side can write next year’s preface if you want to.

If you like it as it is, I wish you would cable “Yes.” My cable address is “Sevenels, Boston.” There is no need of putting any name on, and if you will just cable: “Sevenels, Boston, Yes” I shall understand. I don’t know whether you are allowed to use [unreadable] addresses now[.] And then if you will tell me the price of the cable, I will send it over to you at once. The time is so short that Ferris Greenslet feels we must start to print as quickly as possible. As it is now, we shall come out later than any of the rest of the series.

I received this morning your letter of January 16th. You see how long it takes letters to come. You will by this time have got my letter saying I received all your poems safely. Your contribution is entirely decided upon, including “Whitechapel,” but I am still waiting to hear what Hilda is going to do after she receives my letter, what Flint is going to do in regard to substituting something for “Evil,” and what you wish to do in regard to our poems. You say in this letter to do exactly what I like about my poems, which looks to me as if you did not like any of them very much. I wish you would write a little more fully, as I want to please you, and so does Fletcher, but of course we must have some definite word to go on. If I only knew these things, we could start printing the poems and print the Preface later, but as it is we are completely hung up until we hear from you more fully, so I hope you will answer right straight away. I hope, in fact, that you will have answered long before you got this letter. It takes so long for letters to come and go now. You seem to be constantly surprised that you have not had answers from me, when I have written immediately on receiving your letters. It is awfully discouraging about the length of time it takes, and makes doing business between England and America fearfully hard. I dread your next letters, I am afraid that you will be hurt at something I may have said. In explaining things flat-footedly and just as they are, one is apt to make them sound more severe than they are intended; but surely, we have worked so long together now; and have got along so well that even in cases where we may disagree or where we may have some reason to want proof of reprove the other fellow’s actions, we can at least realize that the same remarks made in conversation would have quite a different sound; and I am sure that you must realize by this time that I am so loyal as though I were English by immediate birth and not merely a couple of hundred years ago, and that under those circumstances you will take anything I may say, as I shall always take anything you may say, as friendship in disagreement, if we do disagree, but always in friendship. I feel very strongly about this, for there are no people to whom I cling more closely than I do to you and Hilda, and although you did hurt me about Flint’s review, and I did feel it necessary to write as I did, still none of those things interfere with the main current, and that you must always believe.

I had a very nice letter from Lawrence some days ago. If he was sore at one time, he is entirely over it now, and everything is all right in that quarter. I am having rather a bad time here, as I am the subject of a couple of nasty attacks: one in “Reedy’s Mirror,” and one in the “New York Times.” But Fletcher has answered the “Mirror,” and Louis Untermeyer writes me that he intends to defend me in the “Chicago Evening Post.” There is no doubt about it, that poetry is a vital issue over here now, and people get as excited about it as they do over politics.

I think I wrote you that Fletcher and I had taken our poems away from the “Others” Anthology, which I am sure is a good move. I suppose we shall all appear in Harriet’s Anthology, and I do not think that the “Others” Anthology has a chance. Fletcher saw a letter from Eliot yesterday, written from London, in which he says that Ezra’s Catholic Anthology is not selling well at all. They tell me it is out here, but there have been no advertisements and no reviews that I have seen, so if it came out, it must have come out singularly quietly. On the other hand, none of us can do anything without creating a stir which shows interest, and I think everything is going really very well, and I think this new Anthology will clinch it. I think on the whole it is better than last year’s. But I do hope you can see your way to leaving the Preface as it is, as I am quite convinced that the public over here, with whom we have our largest sale, need just this Preface and will appreciate it.

If you have not already written definitely about Fletcher’s and my poems, please do so, and do not forget to cable, as soon as you get this, about the Preface, because we ought to start on the printing at once. Also please tell Hilda to answer about her poems, because I cannot do anything until I get all these things settled.
I am sending this off in a hurry to catch the steamer, the censor business does take so long with letters.
